If you have ever flown in Asian countries, you quickly realize that the problem is the "personal space" and "community awareness" issues we Americans have. If you block even 4 or 5 inches of the aisle with your body in the US "as you step into your row", everyone stands and waits for you. In Asia, passengers simply walk through the remaining 25 inches or so of aisle space. And sometimes, one US passenger can hold up the whole boarding or de-boarding process by simple lack o awareness, while they dither. It seems to take about 15 minutes to board and 5 minutes deplane a plane in Asia, much longer in North America.

Having said that, the checked baggage fees have only compounded the problem above. Charge more for the tickets and put the roll-ons in the baggage compartment where they belong.
Simple- stop allowing "special" people extra perks for a fee. First come, first serve. No extra fees for bags, no extra fees for better seats, no first class.

If you want to tell a story - i.e. you're an historian or a shrink - you want to make sense, and you actually end up with causes and consequences for the acts of people, disregarding of their free-will or not, following the many Laws of Nature.
If you're a judge - i.e. exactly what historians and shrink claim not too be - you don't want to make sense : legislators have created sense by making Laws, and you measure the havoc you're judging by the yardstick of the Law.
That's Relativity : depending on your point of view, people's actions follow the Laws of Nature, or do NOT follow the Rule of Law.
Then, you may or not believe in Intelligent Design...
If you do so, you assume that everything in the Universe has its specific purpose, guided by the aforementionned Intelligent Design.
And there you are in trouble when judging the actions of people, unless you also believe that the Rule of Law has also been written by the same entity that controls Intelligent Design.
Then the Rules of Nature are just correlates to the Rule of Law, in the sense that the former are yet to be deciphered whereas the latter is plain.
Intelligent Design is the ultimate protection against cognitive chaos : you don't need two hemispheres to understand that.
As Laplace put it : Intelligent Design explains everything but predicts nothing.
IMHO, using neuroscience in the parlor requires to have quite a clear understanding of what Intelligent Design means, and of what believeing or not to Intelligent Design means.

Thank you for this article.  My daughter has an incomplete corpus callosum, and thus many problems with the transfer of information back and forth between hemispheres.  It's very interesting that people with very similar anomalies of the CC have extremely varied outcomes, from almost imperceptible to quite serious in terms of physical, cognitive, medical, social, and behavioral.  It's counterintuitive, and parents and others struggle to understand it.  But it makes sense that, since every brain is so individual to begin with, and since these folks must make alternative pathways to make sense of their worlds, that their outcomes would vary so widely.  Great article, and thanks to Dr. Gazzaniga.

These examples represent natural occurrences of cannibalism, but there are some instances that reveal a problem with non-native organisms. Take the bullfrog (Lithobates catesbeianus), listed in the top 100 most invasive vertebrates and has common instances of cannibalism outside its natural range. When a bullfrog population invades a new pond, it can and will take completely over. What about the grandchildren and great-grandchildren? Well, the adults have to compete with their own offspring. Some individuals then shift from eating depleted natural food and eat their own babies. Even the tadpoles, when confronted with intense competition, will eat each other. This raises a gruesome and chilling thought, fitting for All-Hallow’s Eve, when we have reached a population of tens of billions, will we too, participate in cannibalism? But, this is only a modest suggestion.

comments.commentTitle: Some folk don't have much imagination
comments.commentBody: Doubtless some future entertainment producer will theorize that Walt Disney couldn't possibly have been behind the Disney empire, having declared bankruptcy at an early age, and having no college degree; that Steve Jobs couldn't possibly have generated the technology that he did (without a corporation behind him to start with); and that the Beatles couldn't have created the music they did, as they were musically illiterate.  What it boils down to is that the nay sayers have too little imagination to conceive that anyone could do great things, because if they were in that set of circumstances, they couldn't do it themselves.  Genius knows no lineage, no title, no corporate attachments. It pops up here and there, and cannot be predicted.  Some people are terrified of this, as it puts in question their concept of self worth which is based not on their own intellect and potential, but on money, title, or a  family name.  The theory of Shakespeare's authorship would have come about because of the perceived audacity of a commoner showing up the aristocracy. How dare a commoner outshine their own brilliance (however dull and unimaginative). In our own time, creativity is stifled by corporations whose sole purpose is to make money, and we wonder why we get the drek we get in books, film, and television, which cater not to the imagination, but to the lowest common denominator, and to greed. Sad

Twenty-plus years after my divorce, I tell friends that I was lucky to avoid the "toxic" divorce. I had the luxury of learning from others' mistakes when I worked on an adolescent chemical dependency unit which counseled families dealing with troubled teens with drug-related issues. I saw many times the aftermath of bad divorces on teens and vowed to never make those same mistakes. When I found myself needing a divorce in 1985, I contacted divorce attorneys for assistance to draft a simple divorce agreement where we shared custody, assets and no request for child support. More than one of those attorneys ranted/lectured me on "feminination of poverty" but I wanted to avoid getting caught in any "system" that makes decisions for me. I researched and found an arbitration center where a social worker-and-lawyer team met with my son's father and I to help us draft the agreement. I then hired an attorney to submit it in court. Our agreement initially stipulated every other week with each parent but he and I had the understanding that we would adjust it between ourselves as our son aged to allow longer periods of time at each home with each parent. Our agreement also stipulated that Minneapolis was our son's home and if either parent chose to leave the area, s/he was choosing to leave the child which removed the opposing parent out of the equation. Our son is now in his late 20s and we all can meet for holidays and to celebrate his personal successes without the rancor so common to these situations. I've met men and women who have had their lives destroyed by divorce and consider myself very fortunate to have been able to avoid the "toxic divorce."

the first 'crisis' comes when you have unknowingly signed on for two different marriages. Then comes the blaming or you can acknowledge you both really don't know what marriage is and find a new definition you can both live with. You do make the best decision you can when you choose to marry; it just changes. I found that it didn't matter exactly who I married, I would have married the same person. I found I spent my years being married learning about myself, getting counseling and learning how to live more intelligently.  I think my husband, who wouldn't go to counseling, learned from my counseling sessions. He did listen to me, for the sake of the kids.  It wasn't a perfect time for all but it grew to be as honest, loving, and as peaceful as we could make it. What we always agreed upon was the fact that our children, who we brought into the world, needed both of us under the same roof with them and we needed to turn ourselves inside out to make it work, peacefully. I may have done most of the hard work but I am a much better person for it and we have two children who love and respect us. They are starting out much better in the world than we did.

Back a few years, music friends of mine in Ithaca, NY told me that some of their friends who were getting divorced had arranged a sort of divorce "ceremony," mainly as something to help the children, to show them that parents can still get along and still love them.

I thought, hmmmm, this would be a good thing to write a song for, so I did, and it's called "Happy Divorce Day."

Over the years I have heard from divorced people who've told me that the song has given them some comfort. I just posted it at my website so you can download it if you are going through a divorce. I hope it will help.

www.christinelavin.com/index.php?page=songs&category=Shining_My_Flas...

Good luck -- Christine Lavin
